message_1: A nuclear power plant generates 1000 MW of electricity by utilizing nuclear fission reactions. Calculate the amount of fuel required per day in Kg, given that the efficiency of conversion of mass to energy is 0.1%.
message_2:
To calculate the amount of fuel required per day, we need to use the famous equation by Albert Einstein, E=mc^2, where E is the energy produced, m is the mass of the fuel, and c is the speed of light (approximately 3 x 10^8 m/s).

First, we need to convert the power generated (1000 MW) to energy per day. 

1 MW = 1 x 10^6 W

1000 MW = 1000 x 10^6 W

Energy per day = Power x Time

Time = 24 hours = 24 x 60 x 60 seconds (since we need to convert hours to seconds)

Energy per day = 1000 x 10^6 W x 24 x 60 x 60 s = 8.64 x 10^13 Joules

Now, we know that the efficiency of conversion of mass to energy is 0.1%. Therefore, only 0.1% of the fuel mass is converted into energy. 

Energy produced = Efficiency x (mc^2)

8.64 x 10^13 J = 0.001 x m x (3 x 10^8 m/s)^2

8.64 x 10^13 J = 0.001 x m x 9 x 10^16 J/kg

To find the mass of the fuel (m), we can rearrange the equation:

m = (8.64 x 10^13 J) / (0.001 x 9 x 10^16 J/kg)

m â‰ˆ 9.6 x 10^2 kg

So, the amount of fuel required per day is approximately 960 kg.
